How did you get the job in Woolworths then?
I just went down and applied for it.
Was this after you'd left school?
Yes.
So you left school first and then you went looking for a job.
Yes.
So did you need any testimonials or something from school?
No.
I had a card that we had at that time.
I think it's here somewhere.
Oh, is it?
So what did that have on it?
Can you remember?
What kind of pupil I'd been and punctuality on the attendance.
Said I was a good worker and things like that.
So I had the job straight away.
But you said the hours didn't really suit you.
No. Saturday it was really late.
It would be about half past seven by the time I got home.
It is late.
It's hardly.
It was finishing at quarter past six.
The doors were shut.
But we had to put everything on the counter, out ready,
waiting for them to come up from underneath Woolworths on trolleys
and putting them all out on the counter to be right for Monday.
So that took time.
Were you working six days a week there then?
Yes, six days a week.
Can you remember how much you were paid?
Yes, one pound sixteen and a penny.
And by the time I'd spent bus fare in and all that, there wasn't nothing much left.
And then you said your friend was also working there?
Not in Woolworths, no.
She was working in an office.
She was a bit busy, so she was off every Saturday.
So did she decide to go to the factory as well?
No, just me.
So how did you go about getting a job?
I went down to the factory.
So which factory was this then?
Smiths Crisps, which is Walker's now, see.
So what happened when you went down?
I had the job straight away.
So what did they ask you when you got there?
I wanted to leave Woolworths and things like that.
See how long I'd been working there.
It was only a matter of months really I'd been working there.
So I enjoyed working in the factory better than the shop.
Why was that then?
I think it's the camaraderie of the girls, you know.
It was nice.
And we used to have music played to us and things like that.
Time used to pass quite quickly then.
Can you remember your first day there?
Because everything was new.
Oh, the noise.
The noise of the tins.
I couldn't get over the noise there.
But you get used to it.
You don't notice it after a while.
So on your first day, did somebody take you to where you were going to work
and show you what to do?
Yes, yes.
The supervisor showed me what I was to do.
I wasn't on the job that I was after.
But there was, on the tins at that time,
there was a label glued all the way around.
And we had to stamp different numbers on them.
And that's what I was doing at that time.
And stacking the tins, they had to be ready for the lorries to come in.
We had to do ten high and ten across
To get them up to the top, we used to put three on the last,
lift three tins, one on top of each other at the end.
So the crisps were put into tins, were they?
Yes, tins at that time.
I didn't know that.
Who didn't know?
Yes, there used to be 18 packets in each tin.
Yes.
And then after, of course, they took me from that job
to learn how to do this boxing, they called it.
But it was just putting the packets in the tins.
Did you prefer that?
Yes, oh yes.
So why did you prefer that, do you think?
It kept you more busy, the timer quicker.
So you were working in that section, Mew,
and when we spoke before, you described yourself as a boxer.
Yes, that's right, yes.
So that's the job you were doing, a boxer.
And there was a tin department.
Older women were cleaning the tins out and all that.
And we used to have a stack of lids on our table.
And then the girls used to bring the tins to us at that time.
But then they put a machine in,
and we were either side of this machine,
there was rollers and the tins would be coming down that.
A woman taking them off the hooks,
and she'd been cleaned through this machine.
And we used to take two off at a time.
And then we had big trolleys with the tin trays on,
18 one side, 18 the other side.
And that's how we used to put them in the tins then, you know.
Put the lids on them, stack them one side on our table,
then the laballer would come over, take that, take them off,
and these labels would go around them.
Was this where you were a boxer?
Yes.
Was it quite hard work then?
Yes, it was really.
And by picking up so many packets of the crisps,
you'd wear the front of your fingers off.
Would it be painful then?
Yes, painful then, see, after a while.
And then they started having the nurse then
to examine her fingers every morning.
Oh gosh, every morning?
Yes, every morning.
Quite thorough then.
Oh yes.
So would she ever take anybody off the line?
No, I'd never remember her doing that, just to check.
Or if any of us were ill, we could go up to see her, you know.
With a headache or anything like that.
Did you ever go and see her?
No, no.
Only once, I was home that particular morning,
I was going to go to the dentist.
I'd ramped into a thick.
I'd gone down to this little shop in the corner
where the hairdresser's is now,
and to get some Femzik tablets to stop the pain.
And the dog, our dog, followed me.
And I left him outside while I went in.
But somebody went out and left him in.
And there was a big, vicious cat there.
And as I caught in his collar to take him out,
it bit my aunt, yeah.
And there was a scar there for years.
And I went to the dentist, I had my tooth out.
Went in the next day and when I told my aunt,
of course it was covered.
And she said, what have you got there?
I said, oh a cat bit me.
And she said, oh that's serious, she said.
This was the nurse now, was it?
Yes, she'd been a sister in an hospital she had.
She took it off and she said, you've got to go up to the doctor.
She said, a friend of mine, first of all,
she sent me up to the doctor.
And she said, you'll have to have an injection for it.
He refused, he wasn't going to be told by any sister
what he was to do.
He sent me back and he went back.
And oh, she was really annoyed by this.
She sent me up about three times
and he sent me back about three times.
To the doctor in your surgery?
Yes, just up the road it was.
And she said why she was so nervous,
because a friend had been bitten by a cat
and it had killed her.
It had gone right through her system, something.
And that's why she was on about it so much.
